trans-unit.source: Convert a Machine Learning training experiment to scoring | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Convert a Machine Learning training experiment to scoring | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: How to convert a Machine Learning training experiment, used for training your predictive analytics model, to a scoring experiment which can be published as a web service.
trans-unit.target: How to convert a Machine Learning training experiment, used for training your predictive analytics model, to a scoring experiment which can be published as a web service.

trans-unit.source: Azure Machine Learning enables you to build, test, and deploy predictive analytics solutions.
trans-unit.target: Azure Machine Learning enables you to build, test, and deploy predictive analytics solutions.

trans-unit.source: Once you've created and iterated on a training experiment to train your predictive analytics model, and you're ready to use it to score new data, you need to prepare and streamline your experiment for scoring.
trans-unit.target: Once you've created and iterated on a training experiment to train your predictive analytics model, and you're ready to use it to score new data, you need to prepare and streamline your experiment for scoring.

trans-unit.source: You can then publish this scoring experiment as an Azure web service so that users can send data to your model and receive your model's predictions.
trans-unit.target: You can then publish this scoring experiment as an Azure web service so that users can send data to your model and receive your model's predictions.

trans-unit.source: By converting to a scoring experiment, you're getting your trained model ready to be published as a scoring web service.
trans-unit.target: By converting to a scoring experiment, you're getting your trained model ready to be published as a scoring web service.

trans-unit.source: Users of the web service will send input data to your model and your model will send back the prediction results.
trans-unit.target: Users of the web service will send input data to your model and your model will send back the prediction results.

trans-unit.source: So as you convert to a scoring experiment you will want to keep in mind how you expect your model to be used by others.
trans-unit.target: So as you convert to a scoring experiment you will want to keep in mind how you expect your model to be used by others.

trans-unit.source: The process of converting a training experiment to a scoring experiment involves three steps:
trans-unit.target: The process of converting a training experiment to a scoring experiment involves three steps:

trans-unit.source: Save the machine learning model that you've trained, and then replace the machine learning algorithm and <linkText>Train Model[train-model]</linkText><title></title> modules with your saved trained model.
trans-unit.target: Save the machine learning model that you've trained, and then replace the machine learning algorithm and <linkText>Train Model[train-model]</linkText><title></title> modules with your saved trained model.

trans-unit.source: Trim the experiment to only those modules that are needed for scoring.
trans-unit.target: Trim the experiment to only those modules that are needed for scoring.

trans-unit.source: A training experiment includes a number of modules that are necessary for training but are not needed once the model is trained and ready to use for scoring.
trans-unit.target: A training experiment includes a number of modules that are necessary for training but are not needed once the model is trained and ready to use for scoring.

trans-unit.source: Define where in your experiment you will accept data from the web service user, and what data will be returned.
trans-unit.target: Define where in your experiment you will accept data from the web service user, and what data will be returned.

trans-unit.source: The Create Scoring Experiment button at the bottom of the experiment canvas will perform for you the three steps of converting your training experiment to a scoring experiment:
trans-unit.target: The Create Scoring Experiment button at the bottom of the experiment canvas will perform for you the three steps of converting your training experiment to a scoring experiment:

trans-unit.source: It saves your trained model as a module in the Trained Models section of the module palette (to the left of the experiment canvas), then replaces the machine learning algorithm and Train Model[train-model] modules with the saved trained model.
trans-unit.target: It saves your trained model as a module in the Trained Models section of the module palette (to the left of the experiment canvas), then replaces the machine learning algorithm and Train Model[train-model] modules with the saved trained model.

trans-unit.source: It removes modules that are clearly not needed.
trans-unit.target: It removes modules that are clearly not needed.

trans-unit.source: In our example, this includes the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title>, 2nd <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Evaluate Model[evaluate-model]</linkText><title></title> modules.
trans-unit.target: In our example, this includes the <linkText>Split[split]</linkText><title></title>, 2nd <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title>, and <linkText>Evaluate Model[evaluate-model]</linkText><title></title> modules.

trans-unit.source: It creates Web service input and output modules and adds them in default locations in your experiment.
trans-unit.target: It creates Web service input and output modules and adds them in default locations in your experiment.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following experiment trains a two-class boosted decision tree model using sample census data:
trans-unit.target: For example, the following experiment trains a two-class boosted decision tree model using sample census data:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Training experiment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Training experiment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The modules in this experiment perform basically four different functions:
trans-unit.target: The modules in this experiment perform basically four different functions:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Module functions</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Module functions</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When you convert this training experiment to a scoring experiment, some of these modules are no longer needed or they have a different purpose:
trans-unit.target: When you convert this training experiment to a scoring experiment, some of these modules are no longer needed or they have a different purpose:

trans-unit.source: Data - The data in this sample dataset is not used during scoring - the user of the web service will supply the data to be scored.
trans-unit.target: Data - The data in this sample dataset is not used during scoring - the user of the web service will supply the data to be scored.

trans-unit.source: However, the metadata from this dataset, such as data types, is used by the trained model.
trans-unit.target: However, the metadata from this dataset, such as data types, is used by the trained model.

trans-unit.source: So you need to keep the dataset in the scoring experiment so that it can provide this metadata.
trans-unit.target: So you need to keep the dataset in the scoring experiment so that it can provide this metadata.

trans-unit.source: Prep - Depending on the data that will be submitted for scoring, these modules may or may not be necessary to process the incoming data.
trans-unit.target: Prep - Depending on the data that will be submitted for scoring, these modules may or may not be necessary to process the incoming data.

trans-unit.source: For instance, in this example the sample dataset may have missing values and it includes columns that are not needed to train the model.
trans-unit.target: For instance, in this example the sample dataset may have missing values and it includes columns that are not needed to train the model.

trans-unit.source: So a <linkText>Clean Missing Data[clean-missing-data]</linkText><title></title> module was included to deal with missing values, and a <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module was included to exclude those extra columns from the data flow.
trans-unit.target: So a <linkText>Clean Missing Data[clean-missing-data]</linkText><title></title> module was included to deal with missing values, and a <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module was included to exclude those extra columns from the data flow.

trans-unit.source: If you know that the data that will be submitted for scoring through the web service will not have missing values, then you can remove the <linkText>Clean Missing Data[clean-missing-data]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: If you know that the data that will be submitted for scoring through the web service will not have missing values, then you can remove the <linkText>Clean Missing Data[clean-missing-data]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: However, since the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module helps define the set of features being scored, that module needs to remain.
trans-unit.target: However, since the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module helps define the set of features being scored, that module needs to remain.

trans-unit.source: Train - Once the model has been successfully trained, you save it as a single trained model module.
trans-unit.target: Train - Once the model has been successfully trained, you save it as a single trained model module.

trans-unit.source: You then replace these individual modules with the saved trained model.
trans-unit.target: You then replace these individual modules with the saved trained model.

trans-unit.source: Score - In this example, the Split module is used to divide the data stream into a set of test data and training data.
trans-unit.target: Score - In this example, the Split module is used to divide the data stream into a set of test data and training data.

trans-unit.source: In the scoring experiment this is not needed and can be removed.
trans-unit.target: In the scoring experiment this is not needed and can be removed.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, the 2nd <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title> module and the <linkText>Evaluate Model[evaluate-model]</linkText><title></title> module are used to compare results from the test data, so these modules are also not needed in the scoring experiment.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, the 2nd <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title> module and the <linkText>Evaluate Model[evaluate-model]</linkText><title></title> module are used to compare results from the test data, so these modules are also not needed in the scoring experiment.

trans-unit.source: The remaining <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title> module, however, is needed to return a score result through the web service.
trans-unit.target: The remaining <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title> module, however, is needed to return a score result through the web service.

trans-unit.source: Here is how our example looks after clicking Create Scoring Experiment:
trans-unit.target: Here is how our example looks after clicking Create Scoring Experiment:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Converted scoring experiment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Converted scoring experiment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This may be sufficient to prepare your experiment to be published as a web service.
trans-unit.target: This may be sufficient to prepare your experiment to be published as a web service.

trans-unit.source: However, you may want to do some additional work specific to your experiment.
trans-unit.target: However, you may want to do some additional work specific to your experiment.

trans-unit.source: In your training experiment, you used a set of training data and then did some processing to get the data in a form that the machine learning algorithm needed.
trans-unit.target: In your training experiment, you used a set of training data and then did some processing to get the data in a form that the machine learning algorithm needed.

trans-unit.source: If the data you expect to receive through the web service will not need this processing, you can move the Web service input module to a different node in your experiment.
trans-unit.target: If the data you expect to receive through the web service will not need this processing, you can move the Web service input module to a different node in your experiment.

trans-unit.source: For example, by default Create Scoring Experiment puts the Web service input module at the top of your data flow, as in the figure above.
trans-unit.target: For example, by default Create Scoring Experiment puts the Web service input module at the top of your data flow, as in the figure above.

trans-unit.source: However, if the input data will not need this processing, then you can manually position the Web service input past the data processing modules:
trans-unit.target: However, if the input data will not need this processing, then you can manually position the Web service input past the data processing modules:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Moving the web service input</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Moving the web service input</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The input data provided through the web service will now pass directly into the Score Model module without any preprocessing.
trans-unit.target: The input data provided through the web service will now pass directly into the Score Model module without any preprocessing.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, by default Create Scoring Experiment puts the Web service output module at the bottom of your data flow.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, by default Create Scoring Experiment puts the Web service output module at the bottom of your data flow.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the web service will return to the user the output of the <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title> module which includes the complete input data vector plus the scoring results.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the web service will return to the user the output of the <linkText>Score Model[score-model]</linkText><title></title> module which includes the complete input data vector plus the scoring results.

trans-unit.source: However, if you would prefer to return something different - for example, only the scoring results and not the entire vector of input data - then you can insert a <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module to exclude all columns except the scoring results.
trans-unit.target: However, if you would prefer to return something different - for example, only the scoring results and not the entire vector of input data - then you can insert a <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module to exclude all columns except the scoring results.

trans-unit.source: You then move the Web service output module to the output of the Project Columns[project-columns] module:
trans-unit.target: You then move the Web service output module to the output of the Project Columns[project-columns] module:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Moving the web service output</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Moving the web service output</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If there are more modules in your experiment that you know will not be needed during scoring, these can be removed.
trans-unit.target: If there are more modules in your experiment that you know will not be needed during scoring, these can be removed.

trans-unit.source: For example, because we have moved the Web service input module to a point after the data processing modules, we can remove the Clean Missing Data[clean-missing-data] module from the scoring experiment.
trans-unit.target: For example, because we have moved the Web service input module to a point after the data processing modules, we can remove the Clean Missing Data[clean-missing-data] module from the scoring experiment.

trans-unit.source: Our scoring experiment now looks like this:
trans-unit.target: Our scoring experiment now looks like this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Removing additional module</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Removing additional module</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In some cases, you may want to allow the user of your web service to change the behavior of modules when the service is accessed.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, you may want to allow the user of your web service to change the behavior of modules when the service is accessed.

trans-unit.source: Web Service Parameters allow you to do this.
trans-unit.target: Web Service Parameters allow you to do this.

trans-unit.source: A common example is setting up the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module so that the user of the published web service can specify a different data source when the web service is accessed.
trans-unit.target: A common example is setting up the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module so that the user of the published web service can specify a different data source when the web service is accessed.

trans-unit.source: Or configuring the <linkText>Writer[writer]</linkText><title></title> module so that a different destination can be specified.
trans-unit.target: Or configuring the <linkText>Writer[writer]</linkText><title></title> module so that a different destination can be specified.

trans-unit.source: You can define Web Service Parameters and associate them with one or more module parameters, and you can specify whether they are required or optional.
trans-unit.target: You can define Web Service Parameters and associate them with one or more module parameters, and you can specify whether they are required or optional.

trans-unit.source: The user of the web service can then provide values for these parameters when the service is accessed and the module actions will be modified accordingly.
trans-unit.target: The user of the web service can then provide values for these parameters when the service is accessed and the module actions will be modified accordingly.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Web Service Parameters, see <linkText>Using Azure Machine Learning Web Service Parameters [webserviceparameters]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Web Service Parameters, see <linkText>Using Azure Machine Learning Web Service Parameters [webserviceparameters]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Now that the scoring experiment has been sufficiently prepared, you can publish it as an Azure web service.
trans-unit.target: Now that the scoring experiment has been sufficiently prepared, you can publish it as an Azure web service.

trans-unit.source: Using the web service, users can send data to your model and the model will return its predictions.
trans-unit.target: Using the web service, users can send data to your model and the model will return its predictions.

trans-unit.source: For more information on the complete publishing process, see <linkText>Publish an Azure Machine Learning web service[publish]</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For more information on the complete publishing process, see <linkText>Publish an Azure Machine Learning web service[publish]</linkText><title></title>
